title: Don't eagerly close tty fd in read_secure
body:
The tcsetattr was failing because the fd was closed in the if statement before, where it was moved out.

i tested locally that this fixes #221

title: Bump MSRV to 1.56.0 and update `windows-sys` to 0.52
Add a small example for working out control keys
body:
cargo run --example keyboard
Press any key. Esc to exit
You pressed Char('\u{15}')
You pressed Char('\u{b}')
You pressed Escape

title: Fix behavior of `read_line_initial_text`
body: This makes it so one can't delete any of the initial text using the backspace keys, that the read_line_initial_text method can only be enter by one thread at a time and that the initial prefix will be retained across write_line calls.

title: [WIP][PoC] Return `Ctrl+C` instead of SIGINT
body:
Would it be an acceptable option to deal with a "`Ctrl+C` problem" (issue #172)?
**Problem**: SIGINT leaves the terminal in a raw mode or keeps a hidden cursor, and also, it's impossible to handle Ctrl+C gracefully.

This PoC works on Linux as of now.
Tested with [`cliclack`](https://github.com/fadeevab/cliclack/)

title: Use `out.as_raw_fd()` to get size in `unix_term`
body: Fixes #185. Tested as a resolution to https://github.com/pantsbuild/pants/pull/19931#issuecomment-1732652244 where the line is always truncated at 80 chars.

title: Fix unsoundness in `msys_tty_on`
body:
Two distinct problems here:

1. Potential creation of an unaligned reference if a custom global allocator is used.
2. Potential out of bounds read in some situations involving long filenames.

See the commit messages for details. Both fixes are ported from `is-terminal`.

title: Return `Key::Tab` instead of `Key::Char(\t)` on Windows
body:
On Windows, `Key::Tab` needs to be handled specially.

This affects code like https://github.com/console-rs/dialoguer/blob/master/src/prompts/input.rs#L474

This PR is tested on `conhost.exe` and the new Console Host from Windows 11.

title: Update read_line behaviour to read_line_initial_text
body:
`term.read_line()` is not using the declared term to request the input. It relies on stdin. This is not the case of `term.read_line_initial_text("")`, which reads key one by one using `self.read_key()`.

This commits corrects this behaviour, and removes divergence between the two methods.

If `read_line` and `read_line_initial_text` are meant to have a different behaviour, their documentation needs to be updated. I'd be glad to update this PR if that's the case.

title: Support build target `wasm32-unknown-emscripten`

cargo check --target wasm32-unknown-emscripten

title: More reliably reset raw mode
body: Fixes https://github.com/console-rs/dialoguer/issues/248

title: Prefer select() over poll() on macos for ttys
body:
Turns out that polling on ttys does not work on macos. This now falls back to select if a tty is detected.

Fixes #168

title: Don't touch output config attributes in read_single_key()
body: Raw mode also disables output processing, breaking terminal writes from separate threads. Fixes #136.

title: Update `windows-sys` to 0.48
body:
Closes: #162
And alternative to:
- #161

title: Added blink fast and strikethrough attributes
body: I added the blink fast and strikethrough attributes with ANSI codes \x1b[6m and \x1b[9m

title: Update windows-sys requirement from 0.42.0 to 0.45.0

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

labels.name: rust
labels.description: Pull requests that update Rust code

body:
Updates the requirements on [windows-sys](https://github.com/microsoft/windows-rs) to permit the latest version.
Release notes

Sourced from windows-sys's releases.

0.45.0

As a reminder, updates are only published by request (#2299). This release provides an update to the windows-sys crate. It does not include an update to the windows crate.

This is the first update to the windows-sys crate in 4 months and primarily includes a number of fixes stemming from improvements to the Win32 metadata. Optional support for raw-dylib is now also provided.

What's Changed

  • Remove field cfg attribute queries by @​kennykerr in microsoft/windows-rs#2280
  • Only show visible windows and include x/y in output by @​jessemcdowell in microsoft/windows-rs#2284
  • Linux build support by @​kennykerr in microsoft/windows-rs#2290
  • Slices should use default (optional) type by @​kennykerr in microsoft/windows-rs#2293
  • Version 0.45 by @​kennykerr in microsoft/windows-rs#2299

New Contributors

  • @​jessemcdowell made their first contribution in microsoft/windows-rs#2284

Changelog for windows-sys crate: https://github.com/microsoft/windows-rs/compare/0.42.0...0.45.0

Commits
  • ddf5ebb Version 0.45 (#2299)
  • e06dc97 Slices should use default types (#2293)
  • 2266e23 Linux build support (#2290)
  • 17a5f00 Update readme.md
  • 50b241e Sample: show visible windows and include coordinates (#2284)
  • f5373bb Remove field cfg attribute queries (#2280)
  • 87ef216 Update publish script
  • 6f115da Version 0.44.0 (#2279)
  • 7c65c07 Add Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) sample (#2277)
  • 1bfd409 Update readme.md
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

title: Derive Hash for Key
body:
I was writing a quick console game, and I tried to make a `HashMap<Key>`. Unfortunately, Key doesn't derive Hash, though there's no reason why it can't.

Tiny PR, I know, but I think it's helpful and somebody had to add those 6 characters.

title: Configure WASM tests an try isatty on wasi
body: Refs #154

title: Drop remaining usages of `regex`
body:
This PR drops all the remaining usages of `regex` for handwritten parsers

I ran [a simple fuzz target](https://gist.github.com/CosmicHorrorDev/448e5bf0f1124d5fa7b1291103f62a11) comparing the old and new implementation for a few hours to preemptively find any regressions

title: Fix invalid terminal size being returned on Windows
body: Fixes #150

body:
Bumps [actions/checkout](https://github.com/actions/checkout) from 2 to 3.
Release notes

Sourced from actions/checkout's releases.

v3.0.0

  • Updated to the node16 runtime by default
    • This requires a minimum Actions Runner version of v2.285.0 to run, which is by default available in GHES 3.4 or later.

v2.5.0

What's Changed

  • Update @​actions/core to 1.10.0 by @​rentziass in actions/checkout#962

Full Changelog: https://github.com/actions/checkout/compare/v2...v2.5.0

v2.4.2

What's Changed

  • Add set-safe-directory input to allow customers to take control. (#770) by @​TingluoHuang in actions/checkout#776
  • Prepare changelog for v2.4.2. by @​TingluoHuang in actions/checkout#778

Full Changelog: https://github.com/actions/checkout/compare/v2...v2.4.2

v2.4.1

  • Fixed an issue where checkout failed to run in container jobs due to the new git setting safe.directory

v2.4.0

  • Convert SSH URLs like org-<ORG_ID>@github.com: to https://github.com/ - pr

v2.3.5

Update dependencies

v2.3.4

  • Add missing awaits
  • Swap to Environment Files

v2.3.3

  • Remove Unneeded commit information from build logs
  • Add Licensed to verify third party dependencies

v2.3.2

Add Third Party License Information to Dist Files

v2.3.1

Fix default branch resolution for .wiki and when using SSH

v2.3.0

Fallback to the default branch

v2.2.0

Fetch all history for all tags and branches when fetch-depth=0

v2.1.1

Changes to support GHES (here and here)

... (truncated)

Changelog

Sourced from actions/checkout's changelog.

Changelog

v3.1.0

  • Use @​actions/core saveState and getState
  • Add github-server-url input

v3.0.2

  • Add input set-safe-directory

v3.0.1

  • Fixed an issue where checkout failed to run in container jobs due to the new git setting safe.directory
  • Bumped various npm package versions

v3.0.0

  • Update to node 16

v2.3.1

  • Fix default branch resolution for .wiki and when using SSH

v2.3.0

  • Fallback to the default branch

v2.2.0

  • Fetch all history for all tags and branches when fetch-depth=0

v2.1.1

  • Changes to support GHES (here and here)

v2.1.0

  • Group output
  • Changes to support GHES alpha release
  • Persist core.sshCommand for submodules
  • Add support ssh
  • Convert submodule SSH URL to HTTPS, when not using SSH
  • Add submodule support
  • Follow proxy settings
  • Fix ref for pr closed event when a pr is merged
  • Fix issue checking detached when git less than 2.22

v2.0.0

  • Do not pass cred on command line
  • Add input persist-credentials
  • Fallback to REST API to download repo

... (truncated)

  • 6a84743 Bump @​actions/core to 1.10.0 (#939)
  • e6d535c Inject GitHub host to be able to clone from another GitHub instance (#922)
  • 2541b12 Prepare changelog for v3.0.2. (#777)
  • 0ffe6f9 Add set-safe-directory input to allow customers to take control. (#770)

title: Bump MSRV to 1.48.0
body:
Per https://github.com/console-rs/console/issues/134#issuecomment-1307391821

Closes #139

title: Drop once_cell because of MSRV bump
body:
This removes `once_cell` again because of the recent MSRV bump. See https://github.com/matklad/once_cell/issues/201

I will revisit this at a later point, for now I just want to postpone the MSRV discussion for a bit.

Refs #134

title: Validate minver
body:
This validates that the `Cargo.toml` enforces minver correctly. It also moves back to `Makefile` based testing as I found no way outside of GitHub actions to run the tests.

Refs https://github.com/mitsuhiko/insta/pull/248

title: read_char: Handle non-tty terminals explicitly
body:
`Key::Unknown` is produced only when:
- A keycode is not recognized by the `key_from_key_code` function under Windows: https://github.com/console-rs/console/blob/b3ecb7dd71b40c368f4fd6a18a04a2fe057bb0a0/src/windows_term.rs#L337
- `read_key` is invoked on a non-tty terminal: https://github.com/console-rs/console/blob/b3ecb7dd71b40c368f4fd6a18a04a2fe057bb0a0/src/term.rs#L274-L276

The two places in the code which explicitly handled `Key::Unknown` were treating it as a proxy for an "unattended terminal" check:
https://github.com/console-rs/console/blob/b3ecb7dd71b40c368f4fd6a18a04a2fe057bb0a0/src/term.rs#L258-L263

Since this is only 100% valid to do when running under *nix I've replaced these handlers with an explicit `!self.is_tty` check instead, which is a common pattern in the Term code. `Key::Unknown` is now assumed to represent an unprintable / control key and skipped when being evaluated.

I found this issue when pressing the `Ctrl` key while using the `read_key` function, which causes it to return `Err(Not a terminal)` under Windows (but works fine on Linux). In this case, I was in the process of pressing `Ctrl + C` in order to terminate the program.
It looks like this issue also occurred previously for the `Shift` and `Alt` keys under Windows - rather than extend the `Keys` enum further to support the `Ctrl` key I think the proposed fix is a little more future proof (though you may like to add support for [VK_CONTROL](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/inputdev/virtual-key-codes) for the sake of completeness anyway).
- https://github.com/console-rs/console/issues/83
- https://github.com/console-rs/console/issues/102

title: More documentation improvements: clarifying behaviour
body:
In addition to some minor stylistic edits (see inline), I
- clarified how the cursor is positioned after the various clear functions
- clarify that indices in move_to are 0-based. (I was wondering about that; it seems harmless to guarantee this since the ANSI code move-to sequences that this is based on have the same semantics.)
- document how move_cursor_{left,right,up,down} behave when called with a larger value than possible.

Based on #119; only the last four commits are new.

title: Append final newline in read_line_initial_text
body:
Proposed fix for [issue 112](https://github.com/console-rs/console/issues/112)

Note that this changes the behaviour of `Term::read_line_initial_text()` to make it consistent with `Term:read_line()`. No change to the return value, but a change in side effects.

title: Miscellaneous documentation improvements in term.rs.
body:
This PR started small: I initially understood clear_last_lines wrong (I thought it would clear the current line and the n-1 lines before), and have clarified its doc comment accordingly.

While I was there, I made a couple of further clarifications to doc comments in the same file, and also some grammar edits.

Feel free to take whichever changes you want. In particular, I don't have strong opinions about the first commit ("use imperative tense").

title: Use handwritten ansi parser
body:
# Motivation

`indicatif` recently removed their direct dependency on `regex`, but it still ends up getting pulled in through the `ansi-parsing` feature of this crate.

# Implementation

There's nothing too exciting here. The regex was switched out for a manually implemented dfa. The dfa is represented by `State` which is driven by `find_ansi_code_exclusive`. I went through a few iterations and the dfa implementation seemed to be the cleanest in the end.

There are also a myriad of tests to try and ensure that things match the old implementation. Notably there is a proptest checking off the old regex and a test that generates strings with bytes used in ansi codes up to 6 characters long in an attempt to ensure that everything matches the old implementation.

Also beyond that I tested things with `dfa_matches_regex_on_small_strings` with up to 11 byte strings using the limited character set and I ran another test that tried all valid 5 byte or small strings to make sure they matched the old regex `Matches`. This wasn't kept in the test suite since things would take far too long to give fast feedback.

# Impact

`regex` is a notably heavy dependency, so being able to remove it had some good improvements all around

## Compile Time

Clean `cargo build --release --features ansi-parsing`, timed with:

```cmd
$ hyperfine --warmup 1 --prepare 'cargo clean' 'cargo build --release --features ansi-parsing'
```

### Before

```text
Benchmark 1: cargo build --release --features ansi-parsing
  Time (mean ± σ):      5.395 s ±  0.061 s    [User: 28.892 s, System: 0.697 s]
  Range (min … max):    5.304 s …  5.531 s    10 runs
```

### After

```text
Benchmark 1: cargo build --release --features ansi-parsing
  Time (mean ± σ):      2.401 s ±  0.021 s    [User: 5.150 s, System: 0.405 s]
  Range (min … max):    2.374 s …  2.441 s    10 runs
```

## Size

I wasn't sure if there was an ideal way to measure this. I setup a crate that depended on just `console` and printed out the results of `AnsiCodeIterator` on the string `"hi"`. I also `strip`ped the executable for good measure since there was a large size reduction from stripping such a simple executable

Size results from `cargo build --release && strip target/release/testing`

*Before:* 653 KiB
*After:*  305 KiB

## Speed

I didn't directly test speed so this one is still unknown. I guess a good approach would be adding a benchmark to check the throughput for the new implementation iterating over something like `sample_zellij_session.log` and then backporting the benchmark to master to compare. From the small strings used in `dfa_matches_regex_on_small_string`, the new implementation was about 4x faster.

title: fix: typo
body:
```diff
-provids
+provides
```

title: Add expected result for test_text_width in the case where unicode-width is enabled and strip-ansi-escapes is not.
body:
We have rust-console packaged in Debian and our automated tests for it are failing. Specifically the tests fail when tested with

cargo test --features unicode-width --no-default-features

---- utils::test_text_width stdout ----
thread 'utils::test_text_width' panicked at 'assertion failed: `(left == right)`
  left: `17`,
 right: `21`', src/utils.rs:849:5
note: run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` environment variable to display a backtrace

The version currently in Debian unstable is 0.13.0 but I have also tested this manually with 0.14.1 and trunk and got the same result. I also looked at 0.8.0 the version currently in Debian stable and testing and discovered that the features are not optional there.

The test takes a simple English word, applies a bunch of styling to it, converts it to a string with ansi escapes and then passes it to measure_text_width, the exact behavior of measure_text_width depends on which features are enabled.

If strip-ansi-escapes is enabled then it strips the ansi escapes before measuring the length. If not then the string is passed on to the actual measurement step as-is.

If unicode-width is enabled the measurement is performed using it, otherwise a raw measurement of the string length is used.

I suspect that unicode-width is treating control characters like escape as having zero width and that is why it is producing a lower result. The test already has separate expected results depending on whether strip-ansi-escapes is enabled and I Debian I simply added a new expected result for the case where unicode-width is enabled but strip-ansi-escapes is not.

title: fixes windows composite key: #102 - add composite key
body: [#102 - Text input yields Key::Unknown on windows_term using alt](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/console/issues/102)

title: Exported `pad-str-with` function
body: Hi, I think `pad-str-with` is not a implementation detail and should be available to uses.

title: add shift to recognized inputs
body:
This fixes an [issue](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/dialoguer/issues/110) on a crate that depends on this one, namely [dialoguer](https://github.com/mitsuhiko/dialoguer).

The problem is that shift is not recognized as a valid input under windows cancelling the text_input routine. This allows `shift` to be handled and with that the input of upper case letters on Windows 10.

title: Add VT100 character set sequences to STRIP_ANSI_RE
body:
This pull request adds support for stripping/iterating a couple VT100 escape sequences alongside the ANSI ones.

While VT100 isn't technically ANSI, most modern terminals still implement a subset of them. The changes specifically add support for the sequences responsible for switching between the box-drawing and regular character sets.

title: Allow creating a Term from an arbitrary Read/Write pair.
body:
Fixes https://github.com/mitsuhiko/console/issues/34. Method and struct names are eminently bikesheddable.

Unfortunately there are some public API changes necessary: described inline.

title: Add NO_COLOR support
body: The NO_COLOR variable appears to be a bit of a standard variable for handling this. See https://no-color.org/. `termcolor` also supports this https://docs.rs/termcolor/1.1.2/i686-unknown-linux-gnu/termcolor/enum.ColorChoice.html.

title: feat: unix term add Control-A (home), Control-E (end) and Control-H support
body:
feat: unix term add Control-A (home), Control-E (end) and Control-H (8) support

ref to https://github.com/prompt-toolkit/python-prompt-toolkit/blob/0ae9aa688e0b3f81a29a33015ca1f8a9adb05c6c/prompt_toolkit/input/ansi_escape_sequences.py#L26

title: feat: unix term escape sequences: add Home and End support for tmux and rxvt
body:
for most vte based terminals, current implementation is good, for example gnome-terminal:

```bash
❯ showkey -a

Press any keys - Ctrl-D will terminate this program

^[[H 	 27 0033 0x1b
 	 91 0133 0x5b
 	 72 0110 0x48
^[[F 	 27 0033 0x1b
 	 91 0133 0x5b
 	 70 0106 0x46
```

but tmux is a bit different:

```bash
❯ showkey -a

Press any keys - Ctrl-D will terminate this program

^[[1~    27 0033 0x1b
         91 0133 0x5b
         49 0061 0x31
        126 0176 0x7e
^[[4~    27 0033 0x1b
         91 0133 0x5b
         52 0064 0x34
        126 0176 0x7e
```

see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code#Terminal_input_sequences

other implements ref:   https://github.com/prompt-toolkit/python-prompt-toolkit/blob/0ae9aa688e0b3f81a29a33015ca1f8a9adb05c6c/prompt_toolkit/input/ansi_escape_sequences.py#L68

title: Fix documentation typo
body: `targert` :arrow_right: `target`

title: Added capability to detect when attached to native windows pty
body: This should fix #61 as well as upstream issue https://github.com/mitsuhiko/indicatif/issues/225.

title: Make windows console colors optional
body:
The changes to make emulate the ansi codes for older windows versions are buggy. It's also unclear if this feature has any realistic benefit since people are more likely to run console apps on windows 10.

This removes the feature from the default feature list to give people a better user experience.

See #69.

title: Mention terminal size is rows and columns
body: It would be clearer to mention the same thing for size_unchecked.

title: Return immediately if Esc is pressed
body:
Fixes #66

The issue that this PR tackles is that if a user presses Esc, no key will be detected until a subsequent key is pressed.
To fix the blocking on escape issue, I use `libc::poll` to check whether there is something to be read from the fd. If not, return the key immediately. If yes, continue reading bytes one by one until we find something familiar. `read_single_key` will block if there is nothing to be read at all.
To achieve this I created a `read_single_char` function that will immediately read, or return None if the fd is not ready.

An issue in the implementation was that when Esc is pressed + some unrecognized character, only Esc was returned and the next chars were lost. I added an additional Key enum, `UnknownEscSeq`, that can holds the consumed characters.

##### On key recognition:

The amount of supported keys could be greatly extended. I think, however, that it should be in a different PR. The list is huge - [spec](https://www.xfree86.org/current/ctlseqs.html) + [how rustyline does it](https://github.com/kkawakam/rustyline/blob/master/src/tty/unix.rs). In order to attempt something like this, it would require some refactoring. For instance, make the Key enum a struct to hold a Modifiers enum. Also, the Windows implementation will have to be kept in sync.

This PR adds the logic to detect a few sequences in `read_single_key` but this should be a temporary solution. Since the logic is not too complex for now, I decided to keep it there. It should be extracted once CSI and SS3 sequences are properly handled.

On the other hand, rustyline might be introduced and make all of this unnecessary.

title: Remove termios dependency
body:
Since the libc crate provides the same functions as the termios crate,
prefer to use it, as platform support is better (Redox, etc.)

title: Add 256 colors support
body:
This PR adds `Color::Color256(u8)` for 256 colors support like below:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4331004/89135570-776aed00-d569-11ea-8c58-7f23cb639abd.png)

title: Adding support for emojis on platforms other than macos
body: as long as they have unicode support. First proposed by github user arabidopsis

title: Depend on `winapi-util` 0.1.3
body:
The package depends on things added in that version - https://github.com/BurntSushi/winapi-util/commit/d33486e0c0c7ef73450ac02a563d914906768827

Fixes issues such as https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo-bisect-rustc/issues/89

title: read only one byte in read_single_key unless we find an escape sequence
body: When input is pasted into a unix terminal and collected using `read_single_key` I noticed that only every 20th character was available. I don't think it should be necessary to read more than one byte at a time. (Hopefully no unicode issues etc.)

title: Reset order of size() tuple to height first
body: closes #58

title: Added bright color support
body:
This is one of the major ANSI code people use. Looks like this library is missing it.

Please release a new version once this is merged.

title: Add "Key::Unknown" handling everywhere it was missing
body:
Working on a project. Turns out i need to test that a dialogue outputs
a certain way. Turns out there's no way to do that because the case of
"not a terminal" is not handled! It's a quick fix, might as well. I've
done the same for dialoguer.

title: Added extra key bindings and cursor movement
Make regex optional by moving ansi stripping behind feature flag
body: Make regex dependency optional. This should help cutting down dependencies of insta (https://github.com/mitsuhiko/insta/issues/102).

title: Backspace/ESC are now returned in read_single_key from Win10-CMD.
Fix clear_screen/clear_line on Windows
body:
On windows, `clear_screen` does not clear attributes like underline.
https://github.com/dalance/procs/issues/34

This PR adds `FillConsoleOutputAttribute` to clear attributes as the same as https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/console/clearing-the-screen.

title: Fix mismatched unicode feature names
body: #32 introduced a feature named `unicode-width`, but the `#[cfg(...)]` guards checked for a feature named `unicode`. This fixes the latter to check for `unicode-width` as well.

title: Add repository url to Cargo.toml
body: This makes this repository easier to find when clicking through docs.rs/console.

title: show cursor no longer clears screen
body: Fixes #39

title: fix hide_cursor escape code
body: Oops sorry I put a "1" instead of "l" this makes `hide_cursor` work.

title: Trim down dependencies
body: This removes a bunch of dependencies from the crate or moves them to an optional mode (unicode for unicode_width).

title: Add a method (similar to readline) which inserts a text which can be edited
body: see the `term` example

title: Add support to move cursor to (x, y) position
body:
This also adds an example of how use it.
Didn't test windows support(don't have a windows machine).
